replies.context:
The Constitution also allows for contracts. When you buy your property you enter into implied contracts with both the State you live in and the Fed Gov.

Very few States allow private ownership of real estate. I think in Nevada you can apply for allodial title to property by law, but it may be very difficult and expensive to actually obtain.

In most States and in most cases the State retains the allodial title to your property and you have surface rights by contract provisions. As your part of the contract you agree to pay property taxes and abide by legislated laws, statutes, ordinances, policies and procedures, and rules and regulations. The State's part of the contract is that The State will defend your surface rights.

context: Paranoid much? It's just data capture and not identification and definitely not used for anything in the US for Law Enforcement or monitoring purposes as that's illegal and the government cannot use it to prosecute any cases. The military is testing it for a persistent surveillance system to protect bases in enemy territories abroad. this long term, high altitude platform is less susceptible to being shot down, tampered with or affected by low level weather patterns and it provides a greater safety footprint for troops as it sees farther than current systems. get a life people.

replies.context:
Sure it is. 

How are they "testing" it then? Obviously you need to know if it works for its intended purpose.

They are testing it by turning it on to see what they see, making sure that it operates at the altitudes that the builder advertised, testing the effects of weather and other things such as temperature fluctuations, how winds affect them. They test the quality of the video and the data link that transmits the data. You can track a vehicle from point A to point B, as long as you don't violate a persons privacy by identifying who they are, by not running their license plate or their address or finding out their name through those queries. They are just making sure that it works as advertised. The Government can legally watch you, they just can't legally do anything to you based upon the principal of expected privacy. Now if you are outdoors committing a crime where anyone can see you and they just happen to see it too, then yes they can affect an action to make an arrest for that crime, just not anywhere where you expect be private, like the inside of your house unless they have a warrant to do so.

It is surveillance. And no, they DO NOT have that right. But just try to stop them. Do you honestly believe thete is no way  now to watch you inside your home? Ha! The only thing they may lack is the  reason or the will.
Soon enough the ability to do that en masse will be available as well.
Ugly world a comin' man. Glad I won't be here. Sorry for those who will be.

Wow, the paranoia runs deep with you. You obviously do not understand the laws governing surveillance and yes they DO HAVE the right to collect data, they just can't use it without cause. The data being collected for these tests are simply for ensuring that the systems themselves works. They aren't running plates and addresses and names, they just want to make sure that it works. 
As for the surveillance systems themselves, yes they can see inside your house; infrared and thermal imaging have been around a long time and it doesn't make much sense for the military to not to be able to see what's inside something when they are trying to perceive a threat and as I said before, Law Enforcement can do it already but they need a warrant to do so.
Troops ?  You think ?

We've been using Persistent Surveillance Systems for years for both military and Homeland Security reasons, this is just a new type, if it was being developed for Homeland Security then it wouldn't have been funded or requested by DOD, granted it could eventually trickle down to DHS but it's not on their radar right now. The PSS systems that the military is using now has been able to detect multiple incursions at our forward operating bases, DHS has been using them to detect illegal border crossings and aircraft and vessel incursions in to US airspace and territorial waters and for detecting smuggling activities both foreign and domestic.

It is sad to see this generation so willing to throw away freedoms that our ancestors fought and died for. There was a time when U.S. citizens didn't want an overbearing government controlling every detail in their lives. Freedoms are being lost a piece at a time. The ignorant liberal masses will cheer as the totalitarian government takes total control.
